TEXT.English: [TAB]A safari, from a Swahili word meaning a long journey, is an overland journey (especially in Africa).[PARAGRAPH:1]Safari as a distinctive way of hunting was popularized by US author Ernest Hemingway and president Theodore Roosevelt. A safari may consist of several days or even weeks-long journey and camping in the bush or jungle, while pursuing big game. Nowadays, it's often used to describe tours through African national parks to watch or hunt wildlife. [TAB]Hunters are usually tourists, accompanied by (licensed and highly regulated) professional hunters, local guides, skinners and porters in more difficult terrains. A special safari type is the solo-safari where all the license acquiring, stalking, preparation and outfitting is done by the hunter himself.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]safari来自斯瓦希里语，意思是长途旅行，是一种陆路旅行（尤其是在非洲）[段落：1]狩猎作为一种独特的狩猎方式，被美国作家欧内斯特·海明威和西奥多·罗斯福总统所推广。一次狩猎可能包括几天甚至几周的长途旅行，在丛林或丛林中露营，同时追求大型猎物。现在，它经常被用来描述通过非洲国家公园观看或狩猎野生动物的旅行。

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mahardlek[COLOR_REVERT], the Thai replacement for the the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Rifleman[COLOR_REVERT], begins with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Woodsman I[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.
TEXT.Chinese: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mahardlek[COLOR_REVERT]是泰国替代[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]步枪兵[COLOR_REVERT]的泰语版本，从[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Woodsman I[COLOR_REVERT]开始。

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Savanna Hunter[COLOR_REVERT], the Ethiopian replacement for the the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Pistolier[COLOR_REVERT], can enter [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rainforest[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungle[COLOR_REVERT] and begins with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Mobility[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sentry[COLOR_REVERT] promotions.
TEXT.Chinese: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Savanna Hunter[COLOR_REVERT]，埃塞俄比亚替代[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]手枪式骑兵[COLOR_REVERT]，可以进入[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]雨林[COLOR_REVERT]和[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]丛林[COLOR_REVERT]并从[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]移动性[COLOR_REVERT]和[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sentry[COLOR_REVERT]促销活动开始。

TEXT.English: Chevalier
TEXT.Chinese: 法兰西圣骑士

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mali Empire flourished because of trade above all else. It contained three immense gold mines within its borders unlike the Ghana Empire, which was only a transit point for gold. The empire taxed every ounce of gold or salt that entered its borders. By the beginning of the 14th century, Mali was the source of almost half the Old World's gold exported from mines in Bambuk, Boure and Galam. There was no standard currency throughout the realm, but several forms were prominent by region. The Sahelian and Saharan towns of the Mali Empire were organized as both staging posts in the long-distance caravan trade and trading centers for the various West African products. At Taghaza, for example, salt was exchanged; at Takedda, copper. Ibn Battuta observed the employment of slave labor in both towns. During most of his journey, Ibn Battuta traveled with a retinue that included slaves, most of whom carried goods for trade but would also be traded as slaves. On the return from Takedda to Morocco, his caravan transported 600 female slaves, suggesting that slavery was a substantial part of the commercial activity of the empire.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]马里帝国的繁荣是因为贸易高于一切。它境内有三座巨大的金矿，与加纳帝国不同，加纳帝国只是黄金的中转站。帝国对进入国境的每一盎司黄金或盐都征税。到14世纪初，马里几乎是旧世界一半黄金出口的来源地，这些黄金来自班布克、布尔和加拉姆的矿山。整个王国都没有标准货币，但各地区的货币形式却很突出。马里帝国的萨赫勒和撒哈拉城镇被组织成长途大篷车贸易的中转站和各种西非产品的贸易中心。例如，在塔哈扎，交换盐；在塔克达，交换铜。伊本·巴图塔观察了这两个城镇雇佣奴隶的情况。在他的大部分旅程中，伊本·巴图塔和包括奴隶在内的随从一起旅行，他们大多数携带货物进行贸易，但也会作为奴隶进行交易。从塔克达返回摩洛哥后，他的商队运送了600名女奴，这表明奴隶制度是帝国商业活动的重要组成部分。

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Blowgunner[COLOR_REVERT], the Mayan replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Skirmisher[COLOR_REVERT], is able to enter [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungle[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rainforest[COLOR_REVERT], provides food to the nearest city when it wins a fight and has a higher chance to withdraw from combat.
TEXT.Chinese: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Blowgunner[COLOR_REVERT]是玛雅人对[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]游击兵[COLOR_REVERT]的替代品，能够进入[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]丛林[COLOR_REVERT]和[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]雨林[COLOR_REVERT]，在最近的城市赢得战斗时为其提供食物，并有更高的机会退出战斗。

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Naffatun[COLOR_REVERT], the Iranian replacement for the the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Grenadier[COLOR_REVERT], does more collateral damage.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Kallarani[COLOR_REVERT], the Tamil replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Swordsman[COLOR_REVERT], has a combat bonus against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Light Cavalry Units[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry Units[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Chinese: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Kallarani[COLOR_REVERT]是泰米尔人对[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]重骑兵[COLOR_REVERT]的替代品，对[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]轻骑兵单位[COLOR_REVERT]和[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]重骑兵单位[COLOR_REVERT]有战斗加成。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The "Hetairoi" (Companions) were Alexander's elite cavalry and the primary offensive arm of his army. A master of cavalry tactics, Alexander would hold them back during the opening part of the battle, committing them at the decisive point to charge the shaken foe, often leading the attack himself. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Alexander's father, Philip of Macedon, created the Companions, who were originally his closest retainers, picked from the Macedonian nobility. As their numbers rose, additional young noblemen were recruited from Thessaly and other parts of the Greek world. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]The Companions were organized into "ilai" (wings) of about 200 men, under the command of close personal friends of the king. They generally wore the usual Boeotian helmet with plumes out the top, a dyed cloak and cuirass. Underneath, they wore linen or leather corslets reinforced with metal scales. They carried long thrusting spears and a short sword; few carried shields unless afoot. Occasionally, Alexander armed them with javelins for specific battles. Their mounts were the best that Greece had to offer - short, sturdy animals trained for war. The horses were partially armored, likely with leather skirts over their flanks and rumps. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]The legends of Alexander's Companions have grown with the telling over the centuries. Though their prowess has undoubtedly been exaggerated, it cannot be denied that they played a significant role in victorious battles such as Issus and Chaeronea. And their loyalty was never questioned. For the next several centuries, elite cavalry of many ancient kingdoms would take the Companions as their ideal model.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]“Hetairoi”（同伴）是亚历山大的精锐骑兵，也是他军队的主要进攻武器。作为骑兵战术的大师，亚历山大会在战斗的开始阶段阻止他们，让他们在决定性的时刻冲向受惊的敌人，通常自己领导进攻。[段落：2：1]亚历山大的父亲，马其顿的菲利浦，创造了同伴，他们最初是他最亲密的随从，从马其顿贵族中挑选出来的。随着人数的增加，更多的年轻贵族从塞萨利和希腊世界的其他地方被招募。[段落：2：1]同伴们被组织成大约200人的“伊拉”（翅膀），在国王亲密的私人朋友的指挥下。他们一般都戴着通常的博奥人头盔，上面有羽毛，披着染色的斗篷和胸甲。在下面，他们穿着亚麻或皮革紧身胸衣，上面有金属鳞片。他们带着长矛和短剑，很少有人携带盾牌，除非是步行的。偶尔，亚历山大用标枪武装他们进行特定的战斗。他们的坐骑是希腊所能提供的最好的——短而结实的动物，受过战争训练。这些马身上有部分盔甲，很可能侧面和臀部都有皮裙。[段落：2：1]几个世纪以来，亚历山大的同伴们的传奇故事随着讲述而不断发展。尽管他们的实力无疑被夸大了，但不可否认的是，他们在诸如伊苏斯（Issus）和查罗娜（Chaerona）这样的胜利战役中发挥了重要作用。他们的忠诚从未受到质疑。在接下来的几个世纪里，许多古代王国的精锐骑兵都将同伴视为理想的典范。

TEXT.English: Heqa Khasewet
TEXT.Chinese: 希克索斯人
